scenario:
The S&P 500 Index gained 24% in 2024, while Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A, BRK.B) performed similarly. The broader market is up 53% over the last two years, with Berkshire trailing the market. However, the author believes Berkshire will outperform the S&P 500 in 2025 due to its more balanced portfolio and ability to hedge inflation.

Berkshire's portfolio is now more diversified, with Apple making up only 25% of its equities portfolio, down from 30-40% mid-year. The company has also trimmed its stake in Bank of America and American Express, and now holds a quarter of its portfolio in these stocks. Berkshire's equities portfolio is now split between consumer goods, financials, and oil, with a quarter in each sector.

Berkshire holds a slate of value names with strong dividends, including Kraft Heinz, Sirius XM, and Citigroup. The company has a massive hoard of cash exceeding $300 billion, which provides a cushion, and has only repurchased a few billion dollars' worth of its own stock this year.

Berkshire is well-positioned to hedge inflation due to its energy assets and stocks, including its ownership of Chevron and Occidental Petroleum. The outlook for oil prices is bearish, but further geopolitical tensions or fluctuations in interest rates or the U.S. dollar could affect oil prices, making Berkshire a potential beneficiary.

The S&P 500 may continue to move higher in 2025, but the market looks pricey and overly concentrated in the Fateful Eight stocks. Berkshire's diversified portfolio and ability to hedge inflation make it a potential outperformer in 2025.
